customer_name: Zoological Society of the Palm Beaches Inc
customer_addr:
1301 Summit Boulevard
West Palm Beach, FL 33405
site_name: ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF THE PALM BEACHES INC

citations.narrative:
On the morning of April 23,2024, animal care staff noticed that an 8- year-old female Lorikeet was missing from the
aviary. Members of the public can participate in an encounter during which they walk through the aviary while feeding the
lorikeets a cup of nectar. Birds are allowed to perch onto participants to obtain the nectar and the encounter is supervised
by at least two staff members.
Facility representatives state that at 2:00pm on Monday, April 22, 2024, animal care staff counted all twenty-six lorikeets.
The lorikeet aviary was then closed by staff at 3:45pm due to a lightning alert. After the lightning alert was lifted, two
lorikeet aviary attendants went back into the aviary to secure it as per the Zoo’s weather event protocol. Nothing unusual
was seen or heard by the attendants present during this period.
At 8:47am on Tuesday, April 23, 2024, animal care staff counted twenty-five lorikeets and reported one missing. The
aviary was then closed to the public and thorough searches of the habitat were conducted. All possibilities of containment
failure, fatality from other animals in the habitat, and all possible hiding spots were investigated but the bird was never
recovered. The security team thoroughly reviewed the surveillance camera material during the window of time of the
incident and flagged one guest exhibiting suspicious behavior. According to the facility representatives, it was determined
that the Lorikeet was likely stolen from the aviary by a member of the public. A bird removed from its primary enclosure
and social structure by a member of the public could have the potential to adversely affect the health and well-being of the
animal.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public. Correct from this date forward of May 9,2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On the morning of April 23,2024, animal care staff noticed that an 8- year-old female Lorikeet was missing from the 
aviary. Members of the public can participate in an encounter during which they walk through the aviary while feeding the 
lorikeets a cup of nectar. Birds are allowed to perch onto participants to obtain the nectar and the encounter is supervised 
by at least two staff members.  
 
Facility representatives state that at 2:00pm on Monday, April 22, 2024, animal care staff counted all twenty-six lorikeets. 
The lorikeet aviary was then closed by staff at 3:45pm due to a lightning alert. After the lightning alert was lifted, two 
lorikeet aviary attendants went back into the aviary to secure it as per the Zoo’s weather event protocol. Nothing unusual 
was seen or heard by the attendants present during this period. 
 
At 8:47am on Tuesday, April 23, 2024, animal care staff counted twenty-five lorikeets and reported one missing. The 
aviary was then closed to the public and thorough searches of the habitat were conducted. All possibilities of containment 
failure, fatality from other animals in the habitat, and all possible hiding spots were investigated but the bird was never 
recovered. The security team thoroughly reviewed the surveillance camera material during the window of time of the 
incident and flagged one guest exhibiting suspicious behavior. According to the facility representatives, it was determined 
that the Lorikeet was likely stolen from the aviary by a member of the public. A bird removed from its primary enclosure 
and social structure by a member of the public could have the potential to adversely affect the health and well-being of the 
animal.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. Correct from this date forward of May 9,2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

n
